prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: R Lep 0.035-0.42"
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: High spatial resolution R Lep SG.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
For the lines we expect to be maser in nature, we would like around 0.15 km/s velocity resolution, as there may be narrow line spikes in line profiles due to maser action.
We have performed spectral averaging where appropriate. Post-observation further smoothing will also be applied if necessary.

We need this high angular resolution to probe compact maser emission very near to the surface of stellar photospheres.
The largest angular scale is not as large as we would like for imaging all of our thermal lines, based on observations in the literature (e.g. Fonfria et al. 2014, MNRAS, 445, 3289). Therefore we have added another Science Goal for this target, in which we will probe from 0.25 to 2.5 arcsecond scales for carbon-rich stars, and from 0.3 to 3.0 arcseconds for oxygen-rich stars.
We expect to be able to self-calibrate these data to achieve better image quality.

Individual maser features are expected to have narrow linewidths (e.g. < 2 km/s), causing spikes in the line profiles, so we perform the sensitivity calculation for 0.15 km/s so we can resolve in velocity individual maser feature linewidths/these spikes.
For the high-angular resolution array observations, we want to be able to make 10 sigma detections of compact maser emission in 0.15 km/s that is of peak flux density 70.0 mJy (carbon-rich stars) and 85 mJy (oxygen-rich stars). Since masers are time-variable, we have chosen a value that we believe to be suitable whether the masers vary somewhat since the previous observations, and that is suitable for all our stars i.e this peak is based on the minimum emission likely to be present.
Assuming the equation for a sparse array (i.e. in the worst case), we may then be able to have relative position uncertainties for maser spots of beam / SNR = 0.035 mas / 10.0 = 3.5 mas. If we do not achieve this, then we will still be able to perform very good science using these data, but that is what we are aiming for.
The correlator setup is the same as the for the higher angular resolution Science Goal towards the same target.

The angular resolution of this array is chosen so that we have the possibility to combine the data/a subset of the data with our higher angular resolution array towards this target. It is also chosen based on that we expecting thermal line emission in our target perhaps on scales of about 2-3 arcseconds (Fonfria et al. 2014, MNRAS, 445, 3289).

We have chosen exactly the same spectral setup as for the higher angular resolution observations towards this target, as we may want to combine the data from the two arrays. In order to combine data with the array at higher angular resolution, in principle we only need to achieve the same surface brightness sensitivity as in the other array. However, we have chosen to go deeper than that on these scales in which we expect to probe weaker thermal lines (the high angular resolution observations are more targeting maser emission). So we will examine the results from the two arrays separately, and if we combine data from the two arrays, we will consult the EU ARC on the best way to do this.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: AGB stars are among the main providers of nuclear-enriched material and dust to galaxies, but we still do not understand the chain of mechanisms of AGB mass-loss. Near infrared interferometric observations have revealed complex photospheres and envelopes which are the location of shock front propagation, molecular formation and destruction, SiO maser emission, and dust formation. In particular, the modes of mass ejection and dust formation are still unknown. With the goal of understanding these, we have formed the ESTHER collaboration (PI Haubois) for observation of the AGB mass loss process from the photosphere out to the interstellar medium. ESTHER aims to study 5 oxygen-rich and 5 carbon-rich AGB stars. Here, we propose to observe a subset of these using submm SiO and HCN masers, believed to trace the dynamical atmosphere near the star (2 to 5 Rstar). The results will help answer the three main drivers of ESTHER: 1) Is mass ejection into the inner atmosphere caused by an interplay of pulsation and convection? 2) How does this inner atmosphere morphologically connect with the outer atmosphere? 3) What is the nature and dynamical properties of the dust formation sites?

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics (IAA), Universite libre de Bruxelles (ULB)
Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics (IAA), Universite libre de Bruxelles (ULB)
Institute of Astronomy, Leuven, Catholic University
